Change has been successfully merged

To clarify, your architecture is

OpenBMC -> IPMB -> Other BMC -> SMPro -> Processor?

The SMPro _is_ the processor. I'm actually not sure the MMC should be referred to as another BMC, but it responds to some IPMI commands. I'll change it.

Otherwise, that's correct.
Acknowledged

Also, I realize the process function doesn't currently have unit tests, but it would be good to start.  Would it be possible to write a couple unit tests for a positive and error number smpro might give?  It doesn't have to be extensive, but something is better than notching.

I agree that adding unit tests would be good, but I'm not sure where to start given the size of `main()` in src/IpmbSensor.cpp and how much setup appears to be needed. It doesn't help that I'm most familiar with C, and very unfamiliar with Boost and modern C++.

Is there anybody who might be able to help?

Also, it looks like src/IpmbSensor.cpp would need quite a bit of restructuring to be able to be unit tested - so if it's okay I'd prefer to leave that to someone who's more familiar with dbus-sensors.

processReading() looks like it only takes arguments that would be representative in a unit test.  I'm not following why it would require significant restructuring?

> so if it's okay I'd prefer to leave that to someone who's more familiar with dbus-sensors.

With respect, nobody else likely has an smpro system, so it's unlikely they could craft a unit test that isn't just reverse engineering your code, and writing unit tests so the code passes isn't a great strategy.  Ideally we'd be pulling values that you actually saw in hardware and put it into the unit test.

Please at least make an attempt.  If you need help, there's lots of help available.

Good point.
I've been trying to instantiate an instance of IpmbSensor, but that's the wrong approach. It's been far too long since I did unit testing - so it'll be a good exercise to remind myself how it works.
Done

Can we get more clarity on this?  Are values of 127 or 255 special in the smpro spec?  If so, we should handle them explicitly.  This makes me think that smpro is setting an "error" bit that we should be checking (bit 7 or bit8 on byte 0 it looks like), rather than comparing explicit values.

I'll check with my colleagues. The BMC Interface Specification at https://amperecomputing.com/customer-connect/products/altra-family-software---firmware doesn't mention an error bit, but hopefully that's what's happening.

Reading the spec, it looks like the value is signed?  

"9-bit temperature in °C, ranging from -255 to +256."

Looking at your code, it doesn't handle that signing correctly.  that might be part of the issue?  The spec doesn't specify if it's twos complement or something else for negative values.  We can probably assume twos complement for the moment, as I think that's what lm75s do, and this spec was based on lm75.

Looks like your implementation also missed this section:

"• It is not present (such as a missing DIMM) or if the sensor is not supported by the (replaceable) device (such as lack of
support by the DIMM type for temperature reading). Reading this sensor returns the value 0xFFFF."


...

"If the sensor is supported, 0xFFFF value of the corresponding sensor register indicates whether the
value is valid (0) or invalid (1)."
Done
Please remove.  There's nowhere else that tries to identify a "bogus" value and log it.  Also, this will spam logs if that value ever occurs.
Acknowledged
Are you certain this isn't signed 16 bit LSB first?  Usually these kinds of APIs do have to handle negative numbers.
It's listed in the specification as "15-bit voltage in mV".
Done

Then why is it being read out in volts then?  I would expect handing the millivolt to volt conversion in this code?

ACK on the fact that it is truly unsigned.
I'm scaling it in the entity-manager, which I now realize is the wrong way to do it.

Arguably IPMBDevice shoudn't even support scaling (I'm a little surprised it does).  We have scaling parameters in all the protocols that it uses.  There should be no need to explicitly scale anything in an EM config.
Done
Please add Test section in commit message
Done
These lines repeated 3 times, consider combine the cases and remove the duplication
Done
I'm abandoning this since it's been superseded by https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/69331
why isnt this value also uint?
It's because the result is a signed temperature value.

I suspect they're pointing out that at this point, the value is not a signed temperature value, it's a series of two bytes.  this code then turns it into an int16 on line 341, and that it might be better two have two separate variables for this, a uint16_t.
I've kept the single int16_t but updated the code that does the sign extension.
Done
nit, make this 1000.0 so there's no double promotion going on.  Once it's that, you might be able to avoid the cast entirely.
please use static_cast<double>(value).  C style casts are discouraged in the coding standard.
Done
Done
What's the next step on getting this through review?
Need to get the prior patch merged, which requires input from another maintainer.  I'm sure she'll respond when she has a chance.
Latest patch lgtm
I have given +1 to https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/69331
